newsitem.title: USA: SAFETY BOARD TO WEIGH VALUJET REPORT NEXT WEEK.
newsitem.headline: SAFETY BOARD TO WEIGH VALUJET REPORT NEXT WEEK.

text.p: A final report on the crash of a ValuJet plane that killed 110 people last year will be considered by the National Transportation Safety Board next Tuesday, a board spokesman said on Wednesday.
The DC-9 plunged into the Florida Everglades on May 11, 1996, killing all 110 people on board.
NTSB staff have prepared a draft report on the facts and probable cause of the incident.
Preliminary reports have indicated the crash was caused by a fierce fire in the cargo hold fueled by oxygen-generating canisters that were improperly handled and labeled.
The Federal Aviation Administration was sharply criticized after the crash for its lax oversight of the budget carrier.
In its final report, the NTSB is also expected to be critical of Valujet and SabreTech Corp., the contractor that handled the oxygen generators.
The accident led to changes at the FAA, including closer scrutiny of new, rapidly expanding carriers.
Bulk transport of oxygen generators, which are considered relatively safe when located above passengers for emergency oxygen, was restricted to all-cargo flights.
New regulations requiring the fitting of smoke alarms and fire suppression systems in cargo holds also got a push from the crash.
Aviation safety sources believe the fire may have started before the ValuJet plane even took off and a smoke alarm could have warned the crew.
New FAA administrator, Jane Garvey, has asked for a progress report on the implementation of recommendations that flowed from a special 90-day safety review last year.
Areas slated for re-examination include the oversight of new airlines and increasing the number of safety inspectors at critical locations.
ValuJet is to merge shortly with AirWays Corp and will be renamed AirTran Airlines.
